data.title: Android: Support ImmersiveSticky
data.body:
`SYSTEM_UI_FLAG_IMMERSIVE_STICKY` was added in Android 4.4, it allows apps to take over the whole screen and hide the soft keys.
ref https://developer.android.com/training/system-ui/immersive.html

You can enable this in your Android app using this:

``` c#
var view = (Android.Views.View)g.Services.GetService(typeof(Android.Views.View));
view.SystemUiVisibility = (StatusBarVisibility)(SystemUiFlags.LayoutStable | SystemUiFlags.LayoutHideNavigation | SystemUiFlags.LayoutFullscreen | SystemUiFlags.HideNavigation | SystemUiFlags.Fullscreen | SystemUiFlags.ImmersiveSticky);
```

But if you do it with monogame you end up with your game still rendering at the non full screen size, with gaps above and below (filled with the Clear'd color).

I've done a bit of searching, it looks like we need to probably use the sizes that get passed in to onSurfaceChanged rather than the ones we fetch in AndroidGameWindow.Initialize
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/20555083/android-gl-screen-size-in-immersive-mode
https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/develop/MonoGame.Framework/Android/AndroidGameWindow.cs#L47

I'm not sure exactly how we should touch the rest of the system to make it work best.
I'm thinking if the user sets `GraphicsDeviceManager.IsFullScreen = true;`, then we should try set ImmersiveSticky.
Then we can update GraphicsDeviceManager.ResetClientBounds to update PreferredBackBufferWidth/Height based on what we receive in OnSurfaceChanged.
https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/develop/MonoGame.Framework/GraphicsDeviceManager.cs#L593

Thoughts?
Has anyone else tackled this yet?

data.title: PixelBitmapContent.TryCopyTo between Vector4/Color/etc pixel types
data.body:
The current implementation of PixelBitmapContent.TryCopy to only works if the source and destination are both `PixelBitmapContent<T>` where T is the same type.

This is not a bug, its just an incomplete implementation of the original XNA feature-set. It shouldn't be all that difficult to add transformation from one pixel type to another (thought there are quite a few type conversions to be handled).

Eg, for source `PixelBitmapContent<SrcT>` and destination `PixelBitmapContent<DstT>` ... convert srcPixel from SrcT to DstT, then set as dstPixel.

data.title: Dispose resources not working correctly
data.body:
Hi everyone, 

Detection:
Problem occured when ported from XNA to Monogame

Background:
We recently ported our application from XNA to Monogame to be able to leave .NET4.0 and continue use the latest released (.NEt4.5). We have a WinForm application where you can start a XNA/Monogame where we have an animation that just illustrate a flow. 

XNA implementation:
When the animation was done we exit the application pressing 'Esc' and two code of lines was used:
this.Dispose()
this.Exit()

Monogame implementation:
I can't use same implementation as for XNA since the line "this.Dispose()" make it crash later.
I only use "this.Exit()". The game is started from an using statement: 
using (Demo d = new Demo())
    d.Run()

Error:
If I try to start Monogame the second time and so on, Keyboard.GetState() is always empty and the memory is increasing for each time i start it. I think the problem is that objects/resources arn't disposed correctly, even when its started from an using statement. This will make the application grow until it crash and the user can't use keyboard inputs after the first time.

I made a small .sln project to demostrate the problem:
http://s000.tinyupload.com/download.php?file_id=05943256822998486463&t=0594325682299848646326883

data.title: MonoGame Project Creation Tool
data.body:
The idea is as follows: There would still be project templates in Visual Studio, except now when a template is selected we would take selected options, and do:

```
mgpct.exe type=WindowsDX location=/home/name/Documents
```

and open the project generated by the tool afterwards.

The tool should have a --no-gui option, and with that it just generates a default project with the other arguments it got.

Advantages:
- same project templates for Visual Studio and MonoDevelop/Xamarin Studio
- Visual Studio Code support
- Easily have advanced options, like if the person wants to use nuget or not
  - another idea: ability to have templates/samples and downloading them only in case a project creation is started with them as base
- would be able to have Local Copy enabled for MonoDevelop's MonoGame local references without any hacks

data.title: Added support for MSBuild.Content.Builder on MacOS
data.body:
In order to support the Content.Builder.targets on
MacOS we firstly needed to install the Tooling and
Assemblies in the right location. In this case
/Library/Frameworks/MonoGame.framework/vX.X.X.X

Symbolic links are required to get everything working
right. In this case we need a v3.0 link in
/Library/Frameworks/MonoGame.framework but we also need
some links in the Mono.framework as well.

We also need to add an Imports element to the csproj files.
Now the current MonoDevleop/Xamarin Studio templating system
does not support doing this directly. So a new MSBuild
processing class has been added to the addin. This class
will check if the project is a "MonoGame" project (is references
MonoGame.Framework.dll or has a MonoGamePlatform element) and
inject the required data into the csproj.

The templates have been left referencing the Nuget packages
for now.

Modified the ContentBuilder targets file to Batch its items
this is to get round issues when running under xbuild on Mac.

Updated templates to use a new MonoGameInstallDirectory property
rather than $(MSBuildProgramFiles32) so that we can use the
same paths for references.

It also adds the followiing to the projects

```
<MonoGameInstallDirectory Condition="'$(OS)' != 'Unix' ">$(MSBuildProgramFiles32)</MonoGameInstallDirectory>
<MonoGameInstallDirectory Condition="'$(OS)' == 'Unix' ">$(MSBuildExtensionsPath)</MonoGameInstallDirectory>
```

So that we can resolve the directory correctly on both Windows
Mac and Linux

data.title: Add support in IntermediateSerializer for classes inherited from generic collection types
Request for regular "MonoGame Windows (XAML) Project" template (i.e. not for Windows Store)
data.body:
This is a feature request and a request for guidance:

---

In VS2013 there is a "MonoGame Windows Store (XAML) Project" template, which is kind of neat, but it's only there for Windows Store apps.

Allowing XAML in this way is very cool (especially for games or tooling that might make heavy use XAML UI elements, etc.).

However, developing in "app mode" all the time is super annoying, since (at least in Windows 8.1) it forces you to always run full screen, with a slight delay on opening the app, and no easy way to close the apps (alt+f4 is about as good as it gets, everything else involves mouse, and it's really nice while developing to just be able to press ESC and exit the damn thing, but you can't do it -- App.Current.Exit() doesn't even work anymore, it just minimizes the thing).

---

1.) Can you please make it easy (i.e. include a project template) for developing a regular Windows desktop application with XAML / Monogame? (i.e. "MonoGame Windows (XAML) Project") -- [or otherwise, if you can provide guidance, and I'm able to figure it out, I could submit a pull request...]

2.) It seems this project template is missing all together in VS2015 (other project templates are there, but this one is just plain missing -- might be it's own issue / request, but I thought I'd check here first).

3.) Is it possible to support XAML on other platforms as well (i.e. Linux, Android, etc.)?

4.) Also, somewhat off-topic (I can log another issue, etc. if you like, but hopefully you can just point me  at some quick guidance here?), but the MonoGame slogan "Write once, play everywhere" seems to not be the default state if you're just using the out-of-the-box templates -- in the sense that, I have to create a new solution for each platform I want to support. -- Is there guidance on how to build a single solution with multiple projects in them that all share the same codebase? -- I thought about putting all my engine code into a portable library, but, it would have to reference the mono game DLLs, so it can't be a portable library... right? -- I suppose I could just add the same source files via "Add as a Link" in all the projects -- even then though, what should I do about the content projects? -- **bottom line: Is there official guidance here?**

Thank you! :-)
